awd_titl_txt: Atomistic Simulation Investigation on Processing-Structure-Property Relation of Magnetic Metal Alloy Nanostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Magnetic metal alloy nanostructures have wide applications in the fields of biomedical diagnostics, drug delivery, catalysis, mechanical actuations, and ultra-high density recording. This project will produce and disseminate new computational techniques and basic knowledge in the area of rational design of novel magnetic metal alloy nanostructures. The project is expected to impact scientific areas of materials science, physics, chemistry, biology, medical health, and computer technology. The outcomes of the project will comprise knowledge on how nanomaterial processing and crystal structure collectively determines the magnetic properties of alloy nanostructures as well as the capability to employ computation techniques for material design. To maximize the impact of the project to the broader community, the PI will incorporate the research results into curriculum enhancement, student training, industrial collaboration, and K-12 outreach program. The students involved in the project will gain advanced expertise in computational materials science. In particular, the PI will use the educational activity of this project to inspire the interests of high school students with diverse ethnic backgrounds in science and engineering disciplines.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Switching from contemporary polycrystalline media (consisting of dozens or hundreds of grains per bit) to one single crystalline magnetic nanostructure per bit will significantly decrease the volume and accessing time for information archive. To enable this nanotechnology, the objective of this project is to accurately predict the surface segregation, atomic ordering, and magnetic properties of magnetic metal alloy nanostructures and further advance the fundamental understanding of the processing-structure-property relation for these magnetic alloy nanostructures. The proposed research activities include simulating the surface segregation process in some selected binary and ternary magnetic alloy nanostructures, analyzing the variation of atomic ordering as a function of the size, shape, composition, and processing conditions of the alloy nanostructures, predicting the magnetic properties of the alloy nanostructures with their thermodynamically equilibrated structures, and elaborating the interweaved relation among surface segregation, atomic ordering, and magnetic property of the alloy nanostructures using computational techniques. Atomistic Monte Carlo simulations will be performed to acquire the thermodynamically equilibrated configurations of the alloy nanostructures and the first-principles density functional theory calculations will be used to predict the magnetic properties of the alloy nanostructures. This work will provide knowledge for performance optimization of magnetic alloy nanostructures through tuning their composition, structure, and processing conditions.  Therefore, the proposed research will strengthen our capability and enrich our knowledge in developing well-controlled magnetic metal alloy nanostructures for advancing ultra-high density recording technique.

por.por_cntn:
Magnetic metal alloy nanostructures have wide applications in the fields of biomedical diagnostics, drug delivery, catalysis, mechanical actuations, and ultra-high density recording. For these applications, it is desirable for the magnetic nanostructures to exhibit high magnetic moment and high magnetic anisotropy. However, it has been observed that magnetic alloy nanostructures have magnetic properties inferior than that of bulk crystal, when their sizes are reduced. This award supports research to acquire fundamental knowledge about the processing-structure-property relation of the magnetic alloy nanostructures. The hypothesis of the project is that surface segregation process leads to a reduction in the magnetic properties of magnetic alloy nanostructures. To examine this hypothesis, advanced computational techniques have been employed to study how the magnetic properties of CoPt and FePt alloy nanoparticles would vary as a function of their size, shape, and surface composition. The results attained in this research particularly enable rational design of high-fidelity alloy nanostructures for ultra-high density recording media in the future, and hence benefit the U.S. economy and society.  

Intellectual Merit: In this project, some advanced computational methods, which include the first-principles density functional theory calculations, empirical atomic interaction potential development, and atomistic Monte Carlo simulation methods, have been developed and applied to predict the surface segregation, atomic ordering, and magnetic properties of magnetic (binary and ternary) metal alloy nanostructures. Specifically, the results from this research reveal that (1) Pt would prefer to segregate to the surface, and this Pt surface segregation reduces the magnetic ordering in CoPt and FePt alloy nanoparticles; (2) Pt surface segregation leads to a decrease in total magnetic moment and magnetic anisotropy energy of CoPt and FePt alloy nanoparticles and thin films, (3) decahedral CoPt and FePt alloy nanoparticles would have appreciably lower surface magnetic moments than cuboctahedral and icosahedral nanoparticles, due to a large contraction of atomic spacing, (4) the CoPt and FePt cuboctahedral nanoparticles exhibit dramatically different surface spin structures when noncollinear magnetism is taken into account, and (5) addition of Cu, Ag and Au dopants would help to improve the magnetic properties of CoPt and FePt alloy nanostructures.

Broader Impacts: The outcomes of the research have an impact on a broad range of fields (such as, catalysis, renewable energy, gas sensors, biomedical diagnostics, drug delivery, mechanical actuations, and nano-electronics) which employ magnetic metal alloy nanostructures to perform active functions. The computation tools developed in this project have been distributed in academic community to predict the phase transformation in multicomponent alloys, the atomistic structure of high entropy alloys, and the structural evolution of bimetallic catalyst nanoparticles. Seven research articles have been published on peer-reviewed scientific journals, and multiple technical presentations have been delivered at international conferences. The research results have been added as teaching materials of graduate and undergraduate courses. Through the entire life of the award, two PhD graduate students and three female undergraduate students receive research training in computational materials science and nanotechnology.
